input: Hi doctor,I am a 25-year-old male. I do not have any medical history. Been always healthy. For the past 3 months, I have been experiencing this facial tightness which comes pretty often throughout the day with different intensity. The facial tension usually comes half an hour after I leave the bed. The tightness on my face happens to be on both sides of my face but usually more intense on the right. At times, I can feel it from my neck all the way up to my face. As of recent, I have been feeling this slight burning sensation on my chest to my shoulders as well. Prior to this facial tightness, I have been suffering from this burning feeling on the centre of my chest for about a month. It was my first time experiencing heartburn and I thought it was heart related. Went for X-rays and echo heart ultrasound. Everything came out fine. I have a healthy heart. What made the burning chest sensation go away temporarily is lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol. And the weird part is the same thing helps me relieve my facial tightness temporarily is the same thing as that for the burning chest sensation; lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol.Since having this facial tightness, I have paid numerous visits to different doctors, even the neuro-specialist and they all said it was anxiety. The doctors did facial senses test where they take a piece of fine cotton to touch different parts of my face. I had to close my eyes and tell them where the spot is. I have no troubles at all. I did blood test. It came out normal. They told me I do not need to do any scans and that it was merely anxiety and it will go off by itself. I convinced myself that I had anxiety because of the one month heartburn ordeal that I was suffering from. Even though the facial tightness was there, I tried my utmost best to ignore it. I do not think that I have any anxiety in me now as I try not to think of the weird tightness sensation. However, it has been 3 whole months and now I am getting alarmed and worried that it is still here and with newer sensations as I described above. In all honesty, I do feel that the intensity of the facial tension as compared to I first experienced it, is less. However, it is always there even as when I am typing this. I do not see any physical change on my body. Not sure if it is neuro damage. I am worried sick.Hope I can get some form of advice and diagnosis.

The facial tension usually comes half an hour after I leave the bed. The tightness on my face happens to be on both sides of my face but usually more intense on the right. At times, I can feel it from my neck all the way up to my face. As of recent, I have been feeling this slight burning sensation on my chest to my shoulders as well. Prior to this facial tightness, I have been suffering from this burning feeling on the centre of my chest for about a month. It was my first time experiencing heartburn and I thought it was heart related. Went for X-rays and echo heart ultrasound. Everything came out fine. I have a healthy heart. What made the burning chest sensation go away temporarily is lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol. And the weird part is the same thing helps me relieve my facial tightness temporarily is the same thing as that for the burning chest sensation; lying down, eating, exercising and drinking alcohol.Since having this facial tightness, I have paid numerous visits to different doctors, even the neuro-specialist and they all said it was anxiety. The doctors did facial senses test where they take a piece of fine cotton to touch different parts of my face. I had to close my eyes and tell them where the spot is. I have no troubles at all. I did blood test. It came out normal. They told me I do not need to do any scans and that it was merely anxiety and it will go off by itself. I convinced myself that I had anxiety because of the one month heartburn ordeal that I was suffering from. Even though the facial tightness was there, I tried my utmost best to ignore it. I do not think that I have any anxiety in me now as I try not to think of the weird tightness sensation. However, it has been 3 whole months and now I am getting alarmed and worried that it is still here and with newer sensations as I described above. In all honesty, I do feel that the intensity of the facial tension as compared to I first experienced it, is less. However, it is always there even as when I am typing this. I do not see any physical change on my body. Not sure if it is neuro damage. I am worried sick.Hope I can get some form of advice and diagnosis.

### Response:Based on your description, it is possible that you are experiencing a form of dysautonomia, which is an umbrella term for a variety of disorders that affect the autonomic nervous system. This could be causing your facial tightness, burning sensation in your chest, and other symptoms. It is important to get properly diagnosed so that you can receive appropriate treatment. Your doctor may recommend tests such as an electrocardiogram, blood pressure measurements, or a tilt table test to assess your autonomic function. You should also discuss any anxiety or stress you may be feeling, as this could be contributing to your symptoms.

input: Hello doctor,My mother is 75 years old. She had been treated for TB (tuberculosis) of the abdomen as her ultrasound of abdomen finding was thicken bowel loop. In general terms, it was informed about TB in her abdomen. Accordingly, medicines were given to her as per the advise of a local MD doctor. Treatment continued for three months and due to some discontinuation of medicine it relapsed and again she was diagnosed with Thicken bowel loop as per USG. Again treatment continued.However, while undergoing treatment she lost sensation in her legs and complained of losing sensation in her legs and numbness in her feet and was unable to put on slippers in her feet with difficulty in moving. She also complained that while moving she felt as if she was moving on a bed of soft cotton.Subsequent treatment by neuro experts revealed that overdose of treatment of her TB in abdomen resulted in this condition and she was diagnosed for peripheral neuropathy and was advised for biopsy for proper diagnosis. Meanwhile, she fell and hurt herself which was later on diagnosed that her spine at L3 - L4 was compressed due to felling abruptly and accordingly she was advised to take bed rest for three months. Slowly, she recovered from this condition felt pain in her back and was facing another kind of problem as she could not sit for a longer time and preferred to lay down on the bed.Finding her bad condition subsequetly, we also took consultation from other neuro experts at a prestigious institution where she was prescribed Lupivitin one tablet and Sammy one tablet.When condition persisted thereafter she was given Primosa one tablet daily, Neurox one tablet daily, Maxglobin 50 mg one tablet and Defart 6 mg.But, whenever she was given medicine her condition further aggravated. After about six months of treatment by the neuro expert, she has now been referred to the department of immunology for their advice. Meanwhile, we also took advice from a rheumatologist who diagnosed a kind of arthritis and started treating accordingly. He also started the course of Defzacort (steroid) along with other medicines. The steroid was prescribed with a decreasing dose per week from 60 mg per day to 6 mg per day.However, after taking about two months of steroid course her condition deteriorated and had severe breathlessness. Her blood sugar level also shot up and ultimately she was hospitalized and the treatment of steroid withdrawn. After 15 days of treatment at the hospital she recovered to her previous condition. All of these medications are necessary for the patient's condition and should not be stopped without consulting the cardiologist. If the patient is experiencing any adverse reactions to the medications, then the cardiologist should be notified immediately.

### Response:It is advisable to take the emergency contraceptive pill within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected sex to prevent pregnancy. It is important to note that the emergency contraceptive pill does not protect against sexually transmitted infections, and it is best to use a barrier method like condoms to reduce the risk of infection.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 21 year old female. Yesterday, doctors have checked my blood. I am visiting a hospital frequently as I have iron deficiency anemia. The thing I am scared about is, my doctor asked me why my ferritin has not increased (just the opposite, it has decreased from 5.79 to 5.77) after three months of taking iron supplements. My other iron levels are at 39 which has increased considering those references. But, that was probably because I did not use the medicine correctly, I was only taking 5 mg a day. Another thing I am worried about is, my lymphocytes kind of got increased in my blood: (52.8) - the reference is 19.4 to 44.9, and the other one is 3.57. My neutrophils kind of decreased too (36.9) and the reference was between 41.0 to 73.0.In the last week, I had a viral infection as both my parents were sick. Is it why my levels got high? My WBC is 6.77 and RBC is 4.52. My hemoglobin is also increasing actually, last time I checked, it was 11.0 and now it is 11.2. Still low, but it was good to see that it was increasing. My thrombocyte levels got higher again, unfortunately. The first time I was told that I was anemic, my thrombocyte levels were on 485, then in my second blood test (after using iron supplements correctly it decreased to 380. And yesterday, when I checked, it increased to 435 (reference is 156 to 373).I was also told that I have an infection in my urinary system and he gave me antibiotics. Honestly, I have been always getting suspected about it since my anemia has started. Should I be worried about my condition or is it normal?

My thrombocyte levels got higher again, unfortunately. The first time I was told that I was anemic, my thrombocyte levels were on 485, then in my second blood test (after using iron supplements correctly it decreased to 380. And yesterday, when I checked, it increased to 435 (reference is 156 to 373).I was also told that I have an infection in my urinary system and he gave me antibiotics. ### Response:HMD (hereditary macular degeneration) is an inherited condition that affects the macula, the part of the eye that is responsible for sharp, central vision. Some people may only experience minor vision loss, while others may become blind.

Hello doctor,Suddenly, my right eye got smaller than my left eye for a few seconds (15 seconds) and then it came back to normal. It has happened a few times now. Why is this?

### Response:This could be a sign of an underlying medical condition, such as Horner's syndrome, and should be evaluated by an ophthalmologist. Horner's syndrome is caused by a problem with the sympathetic nervous system, which can cause a droopy eyelid, smaller pupil, and decreased sweating on the affected side. Other potential causes could include a stroke, brain tumor, or migraine. It's important to get it checked out to determine the cause and receive any necessary treatment.

input: Hello doctor,I have an anal fissure, internal hemorrhoid, SRUS, and constipation. One year ago, I was suffering from a hard stool that was difficult to pass. He also gave me Sucralcoat Ano cream. However, every night I was in too much pain. So, early this year, I decided to consult an Ayurveda doctor who gave me some Kashayams and tablets. However, my pain did not subside. I used to evacuate the stools using my fingers. That eliminated the stools, but there was so much mucus released and extreme pain after motion. Two months ago, I went to a GP who gave me some antibiotics and painkillers for five days. During this time, I was always sleepy. I took leave from work and was always tired and fatigued. Earlier this month, I went to another GI specialist who did a sigmoidoscopy and said that it is SRUS. He said that I should not finger evacuate the stools and gave me liquid paraffin and LoX cream. Now, my current situation is that it has been three days and I am very constipated and fatigued. The pain has subsided a little. However, I am not passing stools as I used to before. After I drink water or eat something, I get a vomiting sensation. I get anxiety and panic attacks as I am scared about my condition and do not know which doctor I should consult and what I should do. In the past, I have been operated for endometriosis level 4. As usual, the gynecologist is suggesting a hysterectomy. But since I am in my perimenopausal phase, can the fibroids shrink with medication? I have been suggested Fibroease.

### Response:Hello,

Given your age and the presence of endometriosis, it is likely that your fibroids are related to estrogen. Fibroease, which contains the ingredient myo-inositol, can help regulate estrogen levels and may help shrink the fibroids. It is also important to rule out other potential causes of your symptoms, such as thyroid dysfunction, as these can also contribute to the development of fibroids.

It is possible to explore other treatment options before considering a hysterectomy, such as progesterone therapy, GnRH agonists, and focused ultrasound. Surgical options, such as myomectomy or uterine artery embolization, may also be worth considering.

It is important to discuss your options with a qualified healthcare professional who is experienced in treating fibroids. They will be able to provide you with the best advice tailored to your individual situation.

### Input:
Hi doctor,Please explain about the causes of the IBS. How can it be managed? Please advice.

### Response:IBS (Irritable Bowel Syndrome) is a common disorder of the digestive system that can cause abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits. The causes of IBS are not fully understood, but it is believed to be related to abnormal contractions of the intestines, increased sensitivity of the intestines to pain, and changes in the bacteria in the gut. IBS can be managed through diet and lifestyle changes, such as eating more fiber and exercising regularly, as well as medications to reduce spasms in the intestines, relax the muscles, and reduce inflammation. It is also important to manage stress levels, as this can aggravate the symptoms of IBS.

I have gone back to medication and I am currently on 20 mg of Paroxetine and 10 mg of Fluoxetine, but my insomnia has continued. I was prescribed Ativan (0.5 mg) for sleep, and it sometimes helps, but not always. Even if I take a bit more (I have taken up to .75 total), it does not always help me sleep. My psychiatrist prescribed Trazodone (she suggested I start at 25 mg and if I feel no effect, to take another 25 mg/ go up to 50 mg in one night (but I am concerned about serotonin syndrome from taking another medication that messes with Serotonin). Can you advise if I should be concerned about serotonin syndrome if I take the 25 (or 50) mg of Trazodone? Additionally, should I be concerned about anything else in terms of taking these three medications together?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I weaned off of 40 mg of Paroxetine very slowly but my sleep was impacted and as of two months, I have been suffering from extreme insomnia. I have gone back to medication and I am currently on 20 mg of Paroxetine and 10 mg of Fluoxetine, but my insomnia has continued. I was prescribed Ativan (0.5 mg) for sleep, and it sometimes helps, but not always. Even if I take a bit more (I have taken up to .75 total), it does not always help me sleep. My psychiatrist prescribed Trazodone (she suggested I start at 25 mg and if I feel no effect, to take another 25 mg/ go up to 50 mg in one night (but I am concerned about serotonin syndrome from taking another medication that messes with Serotonin). Can you advise if I should be concerned about serotonin syndrome if I take the 25 (or 50) mg of Trazodone? Additionally, should I be concerned about anything else in terms of taking these three medications together?

### Response:Given the medications you are currently taking, it is possible that you may be at risk for developing serotonin syndrome. Symptoms of serotonin syndrome include confusion, agitation, hallucinations, coma, increased reflexes, fever, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. It is important that you monitor for these symptoms and if you experience any of them, you should contact your doctor immediately. Additionally, you should be aware of the potential side effects of the medications, such as drowsiness, dizziness, and upset stomach, and consult with your doctor if they persist or become bothersome.

input: Hi doctor,My mother is 65 years old (height 4\11", weight 64 kg), and has been doing all the household chores since she was 20 years. She has no problems except diabetes. Since one week, she started getting lower back pain. The symptoms are if she is in a sleeping position and gets up and starts walking, there is no problem. But if she is in a sitting position and gets up to walk, there is sharp lower back pain. Can you please let me know what could be the reason? How can the pain be relieved? Any special exercises or chair or vitamin supplements, etc.?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,My mother is 65 years old (height 4\11", weight 64 kg), and has been doing all the household chores since she was 20 years. She has no problems except diabetes. Since one week, she started getting lower back pain. The symptoms are if she is in a sleeping position and gets up and starts walking, there is no problem. But if she is in a sitting position and gets up to walk, there is sharp lower back pain. Can you please let me know what could be the reason? How can the pain be relieved? Any special exercises or chair or vitamin supplements, etc.?

### Response:It is likely that your mother is experiencing a type of pain known as facet syndrome. This is caused by the joints and cartilage in the spine wearing down, leading to inflammation and pain. To relieve the pain, your mother should start a routine of gentle stretching and strengthening exercises for the muscles in her back and abdomen. Additionally, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen can help reduce inflammation and pain. If the pain is severe or does not improve with conservative measures, then physical therapy or even corticosteroid injections may be necessary. Finally, your mother should ensure that she is maintaining good posture and avoiding activities that worsen her symptoms.

input: Hi doctor,I am a 49-year-old woman and last month I was hospitalized with a necrotizing soft tissue infection on my thigh. I had two debridement surgeries and was discharged after 5 days. I was swabbed for MRSA in my nose and butt before both surgeries and was told I did not have it. For the last day of my stay, I had a roommate who had a bad MRSA infection on her butt and sometimes had diarrhea incontinence during dressing changes. I had no physical contact with her, but we had the same nurse. I was discharged with a five day course of Augmentin.The wound has been healing very well and has not gotten infected, but three weeks after discharge I got an abscess under my arm. I went to an urgent care and was prescribed Clindamycin and told to return in three days for drainage. The abscess did not improve or get worse over the three days. I got it drained and was prescribed Augmentin and told to also continue the clindamycin. That was a week ago and the wound is healing well. They called today and said cultures show it was MRSA and they prescribed Bactrim and told me to stop the other antibiotics.I am feeling devastated by this and wanting to understand why it happened. Could I have gotten it in the hospital? I am concerned that it will not go away. Are those swabs at the hospital conclusive and mean for sure I did not have MRSA a month ago? I have never had any medical problems before and these experiences have been very frightening. Is there anything else I can do to prevent recurrence? I have read about everything from bleach baths and hibiclens to antibiotics in the nose.

input: Hi doctor,What is the difference between IntraLasik and Contoura Lasik?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,What is the difference between IntraLasik and Contoura Lasik?

### Response:IntraLasik and Contoura Lasik are both types of laser refractive surgery used to correct vision problems such as nearsightedness, farsightedness and astigmatism. The main difference between the two procedures is that IntraLasik uses a femtosecond laser to create the flap, while Contoura Lasik uses a special topography-integrated laser to map the corneal surface in order to generate a unique treatment profile for each patient. Both procedures are highly successful in treating refractive errors, but Contoura Lasik offers more personalization and more precise corrections, resulting in better visual outcomes.

Then 26th pinkish brownish spotting occurred, 27th morning I did pregnancy test by urine, it came negative, and at 8 AM had brownish spotting, 28th had brownish spotting too. My social anxiety usually springs me into full-blown panic attacks like shaking, feeling unsteady, trouble catching breathes, extreme twitchiness and my throat close up. I wanted to go for an audition for a singing competition, but I have social anxiety, and it is a severe debilitating symptom. I have been wondering if there is any medicine to take as a temporary sedate as it is enough for me to perform, and to stop taking them when it is not needed.

There are a few non-medication strategies that can help you manage your social anxiety. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is one of the most effective forms of psychotherapy for treating anxiety disorders. CBT can help you identify and challenge distorted or negative thinking, as well as help you gradually face your fears and change the way you respond to anxiety-producing situations. Additionally, mindfulness meditation and deep breathing techniques can help to calm your body and mind in the moment.

It is also important to remember that medication is not a quick fix, and it will take time to find the right medication and dosage that works for you. It is best to work with a qualified mental health professional to determine if medication is right for you and to monitor any potential side effects.

Good luck on your journey, and please don't hesitate to reach out for help.

input: Hello doctor,Why some men cannot grow full beards? Explain why some men are not capable of growing full beards, and can only manage thin, patchy ones. Is this due to testosterone and genetics or something more? How does not being able to grow a full beard potentially impact men psychologically? Can this be emasculating for men or cause issues with self-esteem? Is there anything patchy men can do?

### Response:There are several potential causes for why some men cannot grow full beards, including genetics, hormones, and medical conditions. Testosterone plays a role in beard growth, so men with lower levels of the hormone may not be able to grow a full beard. Additionally, certain medical conditions like hypothyroidism, celiac disease, and anemia can interfere with beard growth. 

For men who are not able to grow a full beard, this can potentially be emasculating and affect self-esteem. However, there is no need to feel embarrassed or ashamed, as beard growth is largely determined by genetics and other factors outside of one's control. 

Fortunately, there are treatments available for men who want to try to stimulate beard growth. These include topical creams and gels, as well as supplements and lifestyle changes like improving diet and exercise. There are also procedures like platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections and laser therapy that can stimulate beard growth. Finally, men can explore alternative methods like makeup and fake beards to achieve their desired look.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,My fiancee is B positive and myself O negative. In the future, will there be any complications in my pregnancy?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My fiancee is B positive and myself O negative. In the future, will there be any complications in my pregnancy?

### Response:There may be complications in your pregnancy due to your and your fiancee's incompatible blood types. During pregnancy, your fetal red blood cells can be exposed to your B positive blood, leading to the fetus's blood type changing from O negative to B positive. This process is known as hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). To help reduce the risk of this condition, your doctor may recommend an intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) treatment. This treatment helps to prevent your fiancee's B positive antibodies from attacking your O negative blood, thus protecting the fetus from any potential harm.

input: Hello doctor,You were wonderful in allaying some health anxiety over some skin issues several months ago. So, I thought I would consult with you on another question pertaining to my son. I had always asked the pediatrician to look at it during his yearly physicals, and they made nothing of it. Throughout the years it has grown a bit and has become darker and more rough in texture. It is probably slightly less than an inch in length and looks like a few small lesions grouped together. Again, I have brought it to the pediatrician\s attention and he was not concerned. Three months ago, I made an appointment for him and my other son with a dermatologist for a skin exam, and I pointed out the spots which I wanted to be checked in particular. We met with the physician\s assistant there, and my younger son had a peculiar spot I pointed out, of which the PA conducted a shave biopsy, which came back as a mildly atypical junctional nevus. For my older son, I pointed out the spot on his back/shoulder, and the PA diagnosed it as a linear epidermal nevus. She said the chances of it becoming dangerous are slim to none. It may darken throughout the years, and they will simply monitor it at yearly visits. Unfortunately, I went on to research online about epidermal nevi and of course I ran into information showing a possible link to epidermal nevus syndrome and all of its associated neurological and skeletal defects. As I said, he is 19 and has no medical issues, is extremely intelligent, etc. In your opinion, is it safe to say that I should not be concerned about those syndromes? I presume it is primarily related to the numerous and systemic epidermal nevi, which he does not have, and I would think it would have presented by now? And my last even more neurotic question. My online research led me to some information saying that a certain type of epidermal nevus could be related to a gene mutation that could be passed along to an offspring, with them having possible serious skin scaling conditions, etc. Again, he has just one solitary small epidermal nevus. No biopsy was done, as the PA did not feel it was necessary. Do you feel there is any need for me to worry about that potential genetic mutation? Thank you so much for reading my long query.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I have bursitis heel for the last seven months not healing in spite of ultrasound, healing creams, exercises, anti-inflammation medicine. Please suggest.

### Response:Bursitis is an inflammation of a bursa, which are fluid-filled sacs that cushion the joints, tendons and muscles. Treatment typically involves rest, ice, compression and elevation, as well as anti-inflammatory medications and physical therapy. If these conservative measures fail, then cortisone injections, aspiration (draining of the bursa) or surgery may be necessary. It is possible that your bursitis has not healed due to an underlying condition, such as gout, diabetes or an autoimmune disorder. It is also possible that the ultrasound, healing creams and exercises were not administered correctly or for an appropriate amount of time. It is best to consult a doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment.

### Response:There could be many reasons why your baby is not sleeping well. It could be due to an underlying medical condition, such as reflux or an ear infection, or it could be due to overstimulation or an inconsistent sleep schedule. It is also common for babies to wake frequently during the night while their brains and bodies are developing. 
To help promote better sleep, it is important to create a consistent, calming bedtime routine. This should include a relaxing environment with dim lighting, white noise, and a comfortable sleep space. It is also important to establish a consistent sleep schedule, with infants and young children needing 10-12 hours of sleep at night. During the day, avoid overstimulation and excessive noise or activity. 
Finally, breastfeeding can be beneficial for helping your baby sleep, as the hormones in breast milk can promote relaxation. If these strategies don't work, it is best to consult with your doctor to rule out any underlying medical issues.

### Response:Hello,

Based on your description, you likely have a case of tendonitis, which is an inflammation of the tendons that connect to the elbow. This can be caused by overuse, such as playing badminton heavily. To help with the healing process, you should avoid activities that aggravate the elbow, apply ice for 20 minutes at a time several times a day, and perform stretching and strengthening exercises for the forearm muscles. You should also avoid gripping objects too tightly and keep the elbow in an elevated position when possible. For your son, it is recommended that he also takes a break from playing badminton and rests the elbow.

Applying warm water or ice can help reduce inflammation and pain, but it is best to consult a doctor before doing so. Surgery is not typically recommended for tendonitis, so it is good that you are looking for non-invasive treatments. It is possible to heal from tendonitis without having to stop playing badminton for a long time, but it is important to take the necessary precautions and listen to your body.

I hope this helps! Please feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I have irregular periods with very heavy bleeding, clots, cramps, stabbing pains in my pelvic area with no pattern connecting to bleeding. Some days, I am so fatigue and cannot function. This started five years ago. I had constant bleeding following coil insertion. Then it was removed and had a miscarriage at six weeks. When I was pregnant, there was no bleeding but had spotting throughout. Since delivery I am suffering again with irregular and heavy bleeds. It became worse for the past eight months. I have IBS which is stress related. I am taking Adalat for high blood pressure, which is under control. I was prescribed Mefenamic acid and Tranexamic acid as I refused coil due to previous bleeding with one and refused Esmya due to side effects. My transvaginal ultrasound found two polycystic ovaries and bulky adenomyotic looking anteverted uterus vascular ++ on anterior wall. The size was 2 x 3 x 0.9 cm. There are no fibroids or polyps or other pelvic masses or free fluid. Then what is it?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I have irregular periods with very heavy bleeding, clots, cramps, stabbing pains in my pelvic area with no pattern connecting to bleeding. Some days, I am so fatigue and cannot function. This started five years ago. I had constant bleeding following coil insertion. Then it was removed and had a miscarriage at six weeks. When I was pregnant, there was no bleeding but had spotting throughout. Since delivery I am suffering again with irregular and heavy bleeds. It became worse for the past eight months. I have IBS which is stress related. I am taking Adalat for high blood pressure, which is under control. I was prescribed Mefenamic acid and Tranexamic acid as I refused coil due to previous bleeding with one and refused Esmya due to side effects. My transvaginal ultrasound found two polycystic ovaries and bulky adenomyotic looking anteverted uterus vascular ++ on anterior wall. The size was 2 x 3 x 0.9 cm. There are no fibroids or polyps or other pelvic masses or free fluid. Then what is it?

### Response:It is likely that you are suffering from a condition called adenomyosis, which is when the tissue that normally lines the uterus (the endometrium) grows into the muscular wall of the uterus. This can cause heavy and irregular bleeding, cramps, and pelvic pain. Other possible causes could be fibroids, polyps, or a thickened uterine lining. A transvaginal ultrasound can help to rule out other potential causes and provide a more detailed look at your uterus. Your doctor may also recommend other tests or treatments, such as a biopsy or hysteroscopy.

I was wondering if you could help me understand the process more. Thank you.

### Response:A frenectomy is a surgical procedure to remove or modify the frenulum, the small piece of tissue that connects the two sides of the mouth or the tongue to the floor of the mouth. It is usually done to widen the space between the two front teeth, which is commonly known as a "gummy smile". 

Braces may or may not be necessary following a frenectomy. It depends on the individual case and how much gap needs to be closed. Your dentist will be able to advise you better on this. Generally, braces are needed if the gap is too large and the frenectomy alone is not enough to close it. 

If you have any further questions or concerns, please consult your dentist.

input: Hello doctor, I have flown very often in the last few years. I forgot to wear earplugs and slept on a few flights recently. On the last two trips, I had multiple flights connecting. I do not have headaches and can sleep fine. I have gingivitis and bleeding gums, and no other health issues. I was wondering if my ear is infected or not. ### Response:Coconut oil has been shown to have both positive and negative effects on the skin. On one hand, it has antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and antioxidant properties that can benefit the skin. It can also help improve the skin’s hydration and reduce symptoms of eczema. Coconut oil is best suited for oily and combination skin types, as it can clog pores and cause breakouts in those with dry or sensitive skin. If you do have oily or combination skin, it is best to use refined, organic coconut oil, as unrefined coconut oil can have a stronger scent and more impurities. When using coconut oil on the face, it is best to use a small amount and massage it into the skin in a circular motion. This will help boost absorption and reduce the chance of breakouts. Additionally, those with oily or combination skin should avoid using coconut oil more than once a day, and should wash their face thoroughly before bed to remove any residue.

For the past two to three days, the urgency kind of feels to be getting worse, I feel as if I will not be able to hold it. However, I am still able to as there is no leaking. There is no burning or irritation or any discharge. No recent sexual encounters and no other associated symptoms. I take Coveram 10/10 for essential hypertension and Valdoxan 25 because I also do suffer from anxiety. I have been under stress lately as I was doing my exams this past week and finished today. The dipstick was normal, and early urine microscopy showed 10 to 100 white cell count. We are waiting for the cultures to return. Also, for the first time, I tried going for a run. The entire time I felt a heaviness in my bladder and felt a strong urge to urinate, even though I went before my run began. What do you think could be going on? My doctor believes that it is either a UTI, or most likely, a hypersensitive bladder due to exam stress. However, there have been days where I have not felt stress at all yet symptoms have continued. I am really worried as I want to go back to work in five days and I do not think I will be able to manage the way things are at the moment. I am worried that it could be something serious, like multiple sclerosis. One and a half years ago, I had an episode of sudden onset numbness in one arm and fearing the same thing, I ended up having an MRI of my brain and lumbar spine which both came back negative. Do you think this could be MS?

input: Hello doctor,My mom is a glaucoma patient for the last 10 years. She has been on medications like eye drops including Azopt, Ganfort, Alphagan, Vigamox, and prior to them Cosopt (which did not suit her). She has gone through retina eye laser and also has been injected in both her eyes almost 22 times for retinal leakage as well, has also gone through cataract eye surgery 16 years ago. At the moment her eye pressure remains between 21 to 24. The doctor says implants are necessary as she can see very less now. Given her eye condition is sensitive, a doctor has suggested that it is best to operate her with Ahmed valve implant, however, it has its own risks. I wanted to know if it is better to try the latest option, called MIGS (minimally invasive glaucoma surgery) like Xen Gel Stent and InnFocus Microshunt as it has near to no complications. I want to get an opinion about this before thinking about Ahmed valve.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:

She has been on medications like eye drops including Azopt, Ganfort, Alphagan, Vigamox, and prior to them Cosopt (which did not suit her). She has gone through retina eye laser and also has been injected in both her eyes almost 22 times for retinal leakage as well, has also gone through cataract eye surgery 16 years ago. At the moment her eye pressure remains between 21 to 24. The doctor says implants are necessary as she can see very less now. Given her eye condition is sensitive, a doctor has suggested that it is best to operate her with Ahmed valve implant, however, it has its own risks. I wanted to know if it is better to try the latest option, called MIGS (minimally invasive glaucoma surgery) like Xen Gel Stent and InnFocus Microshunt as it has near to no complications. I want to get an opinion about this before thinking about Ahmed valve.

### Response:Hello,

Given your mother's medical history, MIGS may be a viable option to consider. Xen Gel Stent and InnFocus Microshunt are both relatively new procedures and have shown promising results in lowering intraocular pressure in glaucoma patients. However, it is important to weigh the risks and benefits of each procedure before making a decision. It is also important to consider your mother's overall health and any other medications she may be taking.

Ahmed valve implantation is a more invasive procedure and should not be taken lightly. It is important to discuss the potential risks and complications associated with this procedure before making a decision.

I recommend consulting with a specialist who is experienced in performing MIGS procedures to get the best advice for your mother's individual case.

Wishing your mother a speedy recovery.

### Input:
Hello doctor,After a course of antibiotics, I have developed severe dry eyes, dry mouth, and photosensitivity. No tears are coming from my eyes. I think I have developed Sjogren\s syndrome. Is there any treatment for Sjogren\s? I am wating for the test. The antibiotics are long gone, but all the things I mentioned above are still present. Please answer.

### Response:Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system attacks the glands that produce tears and saliva. The main treatment for Sjogren's syndrome is to target the symptoms. Dry eyes can be treated with artificial tears, eye drops, and sometimes punctual plugs. Dry mouth can be treated with saliva substitutes and frequent sipping of water. Photosensitivity can be treated with sunscreen and protective clothing. It is also important to avoid triggers that can worsen the symptoms. In some cases, immunosuppressant drugs may be prescribed to reduce the activity of the immune system. If you are diagnosed with Sjogren's syndrome, your doctor will work with you to develop a treatment plan that best suits your needs.

input: Hi,I sprained my ankle while playing soccer. The ball hit the outside of my foot, causing my ankle to turn inward, and it popped few times. I also landed on it sideways in the same position. They took me to the hospital, where they told it was a moderate sprain. At first, it hurt to walk, but it did not hurt the following days. The doctor put me on crutches and a splint, which I only used for a day. It has been a week since I sprained it, there is still the pain in the top part of the ankle. The swelling went from none, to swollen to little swelling. I can play on it, but sometimes I feel pain. I have gone to my chiropractor twice, and it is still very tender around the top part of the ankle and the side of the leg, where those ligaments go upward. There is still slight pain while pointing my foot and turning it outward.My main concern is when I am sitting with my legs on the table, and when I try turning my ankle inward, I feel as though something in my ankle is shifting (like something is dislocated). My chiropractor tried adjusting the ankle, and it popped, but it did not affect the dislocated feeling. I have asked other people who I know have sprained their ankle, but they said they have never felt that. Should I be concerned? I am currently taking Advil.

I have asked other people who I know have sprained their ankle, but they said they have never felt that. Should I be concerned? I am currently taking Advil.

### Response:It is possible that you have suffered from a ligament tear or a dislocation. It is best to consult an orthopedic specialist for further evaluation and treatment. I had sex many times the next night but with protection and took an i-pill to be sure. Next week got light periods that were very painful. But ignored it thinking it was because of hormonal imbalance. Both of us were affected by flu and it turned into a stomach infection with alternate periods of diarrhea and constipation that was accompanied with mild nausea but had no vomiting. I became very weak and then eventually recovered by taking Pantocid, Digene and Zandu pancharishta. I am six days overdue and had slight back pain, nausea and increased urination. I do have migraine issues as well as I am quite obese with a BMI of 33.8. I got two home pregnancy tests done and both of them turned out to be negative. However, I still have not got my periods yet and I have been insisted to check for PCOS and get an ultrasound done. I am worried if the ultrasound shows that I am pregnant. I have gained about 4 kg. ### Response:It is possible that your father is suffering from bipolar disorder, and it is important to get him help. Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition that causes extreme mood swings, including episodes of depression and mania. Symptoms of mania include increased energy, reduced need for sleep, impulsive behavior, and inflated self-esteem. It is also associated with increased risk of substance abuse and memory problems. 

The best thing to do is to take him to a mental health professional for an evaluation. A psychiatrist or psychologist can make a diagnosis and suggest the best treatment options, which may include medications and/or psychotherapy. In addition, you should seek help for yourself, as living with someone who has bipolar disorder can be very stressful and difficult. There are support groups and therapists who can help you manage and cope with your situation.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 49-year-old woman. I am suffering from severe anemia (iron and B12 deficiency). This might be the result of prolonged malnutrition over the past few years. The problem is that I have developed extreme sensitivity to most of the drugs, medication, treatment. In the past, there were many instances of adverse reactions by taking medicines of Iron composition. These include restlessness, breathing problem, and diarrhea. About five years ago, upon the doctor's advice and supervision, I was fed intravenously through saline bottle with some Iron injection to it. Immediately in about 15 minutes after the procedure, I experienced shortness of breath, burning sensation in muscles, swelling of legs, fatigue, and diarrhea. It subsided when I was given an antidote by the doctor immediately. From then onwards I was reluctant to take any of my medicines and undergo any treatment. I just focussed on improving my diet. Recently upon doctor's advice, I took some medical tests and the reports were serum ferritin: 3.0 ng/mL, vitamin B12: 129 pg/mL, TSH: 0.02 \xb5IU/mL (but T3/T4 tests are fine), iron: 15 \xb5g/dL, TIBC: 527 \xb5g/dL, hemoglobin 7.7 g/dL, vitamin D: 18.39 ng/mL. I was also informed that I developed food allergy to some foods. Lately, I am experiencing a headache with activity, unexplained generalized weakness, fatigue most of the time. According to the doctor, I am in a very critical position and should be immediately treated with Iron injections, blood transfusion, etc. But, I am really worried as my body will not be able to take these treatments (as I faced adverse reactions in the past). Are there any medical procedures or treatments on which I can rely upon ensuring that they will not have any adverse effects after the treatment. Please help me.

input: Hello doctor,My husband and I will be using a surrogate to have kids. My husband is kell positive (heterozygous). What are the risks to this that the surrogate would need to be aware of?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,My husband and I will be using a surrogate to have kids. My husband is kell positive (heterozygous). What are the risks to this that the surrogate would need to be aware of?

### Response:The surrogate would need to be aware of the potential risks of Kell sensitization, which can occur if the father’s Kell positive blood mixes with the mother’s Kell negative blood. This can cause the mother’s body to create antibodies that can attack the father’s Kell positive blood cells. This could lead to complications such as miscarriage, stillbirth, or hemolytic disease of the newborn. The surrogate would need to be tested for Kell antibodies before the pregnancy and keep very careful track of the baby’s development throughout the pregnancy.

input: Hello doctor,I am a 34 year old male. I had anxiety issues since childhood. I have been jumping from one idea to another for a long time but it has been three years I have an issue with frequent urination. It started in a bad time for me when I was obsessing that I have HIV. No burning, just slight urethra burning. I went to a urologist. He told me nothing was wrong, maybe an overactive bladder. I go to the toilet every two hours or three. I never knew what was wrong, but I started to obsess over it and it got worse to a place that my mind is in urination 24/7. I almost gave up until I went on a vacation and during that vacation, I forgot about it totally. The frequency was gone and even the burning urethra. Also, I had to remove my wisdom teeth and when I did, I was so occupied thinking about it that I forgot about urination and I noticed that I do not use the bathroom like I used to. But, I got back obsessing about it again and it got to a point that I urinate a lot of high volumes every hour. It comes suddenly and goes on its own. I use to get those episodes every few months when I had stress but since I got the fear it might never go away I get it almost daily now. I do not know what to do. Can anxiety cause polyuria like this clear urine when I am stressed?

I use to get those episodes every few months when I had stress but since I got the fear it might never go away I get it almost daily now. I do not know what to do. Can anxiety cause polyuria like this clear urine when I am stressed?

### Response:It is possible for anxiety to cause polyuria, or frequent urination. The anxiety can cause the body to produce excessive amounts of cortisol, which can lead to an increase in urine production. This can lead to a feeling of urinary urgency, and cause you to need to urinate more frequently. It is also possible that your anxiety is causing you to obsess over your need to urinate, which can lead to a cycle of increased frequency. input: Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,We have a regular contraceptive pill and an emergency contraceptive pill. I-pill is an emergency contraceptive pill. What is the difference between them? Which one is taken after unprotected sex to avoid pregnancy?

### Response:The difference between regular contraceptive pills and emergency contraceptive pills is that the latter is taken to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sex or if the regular contraceptive method has failed. The most commonly known emergency contraceptive pill is I-pill. It contains a higher dose of the same hormones as regular contraceptive pills and works by preventing or delaying ovulation, thickening cervical mucus and blocking sperm from joining the egg. It is important to note that I-pill should not be used as a regular form of contraception and should only be taken in emergency situations.

input: Hi doctor,My mom is 83 years old. She had a bad fall 1.5 years ago and suffered with a head injury with little internal bleeding and a broken arm. While in hospital, she contracted C.diff and has had several recurring bouts with it. She has had a transplant and so far she is doing well with no recurrence. She also has a fistula near the rectum from an abscess. They put in a tube to keep it open and flowing. She has always had bouts of constipation and diarrhea for years before the accident. Her cognitive functions have been diminishing. One of my brothers is living with her and care taking her for full time.She is very weak, but can walk with the aid of a walker. Before the accident, she was fine. But, she may have shown a few signs of slight memory issues and balance prior to the accident as well. Our main issue right now is loose stools with some fecal incontinence. The doctor said that the fecal incontinence is because of a weak rectum that will not hold back fecal matter. Also, the fistula is always draining. When her stools are normal, she has good energy and cognitive function. When she has loose stools, she is very weak and can hardly stand or walk. Her cognitive function is a lot worse. She gets very confused about daily items and memory issues.We are looking for supplements to keep her regular and avoid the loose stool episodes. These are recurring every other week. Being so weak at the time of an episode, the toilet and the surrounding area get very filthy. She has little control and not able to clean herself properly. Her diet is pretty good. We are trying to keep dairy items away, limiting sugar and some carbohydrates as best as we can.We are giving her Metamucil when she has loose stools as well as some ammonium. This seems to have very limited success. She is on a blood pressure medicine as well as on Coumadin. So, we have to watch for interactions between everything. Regarding supplements, right now she is taking Alpha-GPC, Prevagen and multivitamins B for cognitive help, Fish oil, turmeric and Centrum multivitamins.Any help or suggestions to prevent the loose stools without creating constipation would be appreciated. I would also like to increase her core energy, so she will feel more like moving around. We have a physical therapist at once a week.

instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,I am a 31 year old female. Height is 5\3" and weight 71 kg. I have normal skin. I have started developing fine lines on my face. Just recently I have developed a slight depression in the form of a line starting from under the inner side of the eye running down the cheek (photo attached). I think this is the beginning of cheek sagging. Is this premature aging? Can this be reverted with non-invasive techniques like topical anti-aging serums, facials, massages or exercises?Someone suggested me to use Retinol-A, which I have started using and is suiting me well. I have read a lot about the benefits of topical retinoid, vitamin E and C serum. Please suggest the best ones as I have heard that most of the available vitamin C serums in the market are useless as they oxidize easily and do not penetrate the skin. I have seen some videos of facial exercises online. Do you think they are effective? Also let me know how often should I get facials and which one is for anti-aging? I am also trying to put down weight. In this process I will naturally lose some fat from my face as well, but I do not want my facial skin to become loose. What should I do for this?
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hi doctor,I am a 31 year old female. Height is 5\3" and weight 71 kg. I have normal skin. I have started developing fine lines on my face. Just recently I have developed a slight depression in the form of a line starting from under the inner side of the eye running down the cheek (photo attached). I think this is the beginning of cheek sagging. Is this premature aging? Can this be reverted with non-invasive techniques like topical anti-aging serums, facials, massages or exercises?Someone suggested me to use Retinol-A, which I have started using and is suiting me well. I have read a lot about the benefits of topical retinoid, vitamin E and C serum. Please suggest the best ones as I have heard that most of the available vitamin C serums in the market are useless as they oxidize easily and do not penetrate the skin. I have seen some videos of facial exercises online. Do you think they are effective? Also let me know how often should I get facials and which one is for anti-aging? I am also trying to put down weight. In this process I will naturally lose some fat from my face as well, but I do not want my facial skin to become loose. What should I do for this?

### Response:The depression you have developed is most likely due to loss of elasticity and collagen in your skin. This is a natural part of the aging process and cannot be reversed with non-invasive techniques. Retinol-A may help improve the appearance of your skin, but it will not completely reverse the effects of aging. Vitamin C and E serums, as well as facials and massages, may help improve the overall appearance of your skin, but they will not correct the depression you have developed. Facial exercises may help to a certain extent, but they will not completely restore your facial contours. Losing weight may help improve the appearance of your face, but it will not completely prevent your skin from becoming loose. To help reduce the looseness of your skin, you should focus on exercises that target the muscles underneath your facial skin. Additionally, you should look into procedures such as facelifts, neck lifts, and eyelid lifts, which can help restore your facial contours and reduce the looseness of your skin.

This is a natural part of the aging process and cannot be reversed with non-invasive techniques. instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hello doctor,I am 47 today. I went to my primary doctor three years ago with low libido and poor quality erections. Blood work came back as total testosterone 381 and A1c 6.9. Started exercising and lost weight and inches, 198 lbs to 178, 38-inch waist to 32. Symptoms still persisted. The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:

The doctor started me on Clomid 50 mg three times per week.Testosterone shot up to 900\s but symptoms persisted although Cialis helped with erection quality, still low libido. Will attach a note with test and A1c results during this time. So, I stopped taking the Clomid in March this year and had my physical last week.The doctor says my testosterone is 570, A1c is 6.0 and everything else looks good. He says since I still have symptoms, that I have testosterone resistance. His analogy was; like diabetics, their bodies produce insulin but just does not know what to do with it.So, his treatment recommendation is TRT testosterone replacement therapy along with Clomid. I am hesitant because I feel this therapy is overused nowadays, and I feel pretty good except my libido.Sought a second opinion today from my urologist, he seemed disinterested in me doing that but said if I try a few injections it would not hurt me, then advised me to run this by an endocrinologist.So I guess in summary:Do you believe that testosterone resistance is a valid diagnosis?If I do try the TRT, can I stop after a few weeks or a few injections and get back to the way I am right now with no permanent issues?Should I just start the Clomid again, or just keep using the Cialis and keep working out and trying to clean up my diet more?Any other thoughts and advise would be appreciated. Thanks.

### Response:It is possible that you have testosterone resistance, however it is important to explore other potential causes of your symptoms before starting testosterone replacement therapy. Your urologist is correct that testosterone injections will not cause any harm, however it is best to consult an endocrinologist to get a full assessment of your situation. I tried Lithium, Depakote, and Carbamazepine with no success. However currently, I take 50 mg of Lamictal and 75 mg Venlafaxine. This treatment kind fits me because I have lessened anxiety levels for sure. It is my first week on Venlafaxine XR. And the second week on Lamictal. In a few days we will increase Lamictal to 100 mg and after two weeks to 200 mg. I also take Tranxene 10 mg if needed, as well as Olanzapine 10 mg. instruction: If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.
input: Hi doctor,One year back, while sitting on a chair in office I felt as if my back got stuck and was unable to move. I took two painkillers and managed to sit there for a while, but after two to three hours the pain started radiating to leg. I was diagnosed with moderate disc herniation at L4-L5 and L5-S1. I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. Then had bed rest for another 10 days and felt a bit better. But, still in pain and resumed with two to three hours of brisk walking and exercises. I noticed that many joints in my body were making cracking sound while I walk or move my body and they were continuous. They are not going away no matter how much I move that joint, the cracking sound will repeat infinite times whenever I move my body. The cracking sound is mostly from lower and upper back, shoulder, ankle, foot fingers, knees also make that cracking sound and it is painful as well. Cracking sound in knees are felt more when I start walking after being in rest state and frequency of cracking sound reduces after walking for two to three minutes.I got my ESR and CRP checked. They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. I also suffer from severe pain in tail bone area. Also suffers from some sensation loss (not persistent) in left side of my upper left leg, pain in groin area (but not anymore), pain in lower back and upper back. Also a few days back a physiotherapist did some manipulation, which again increased my problem and after that when I wake up in morning both my hands are badly at asleep. Doctors say that discs are hydrated and it is rather some other thing which is causing me problems but are unable to diagnose. The amount of rest I have taken and all those manipulations have gone through have only done badly rather than doing any good. I am only 27 years old and unable to do simple tasks like sitting for five minutes. Please help me, what could be the possible reason for all this.I had some back pain three years ago. My lifestyle is also not good. I do not used to any exercise or walk earlier, only sitting on a chair in front of a computer for 10-11 hours. I have also gained weight of 15 kg in 10 months. Right now, I am taking only Vitamin D3 supplement. I am attaching all my reports for your reference.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:

I took two painkillers and managed to sit there for a while, but after two to three hours the pain started radiating to leg. I was diagnosed with moderate disc herniation at L4-L5 and L5-S1. I was advised to take bed rest for three months and felt better after five months. Then I got some manipulation done with my lower back and my condition got worse. After that I had slight pain in my tail bone while walking and the pain got worse when I sit for five minutes. It got radiated to hips, thighs and it was worse when I stood up from a sitting position. Then I left with no option except bed rest for another four months that is a total nine months of bed rest. After that I suddenly started walking two to three hours a day in a stretch and started doing some exercises. After few days of getting my body too much into motion I felt my upper back getting stuck and again was unable to move and the pain radiated to my wrist and hand. Then had bed rest for another 10 days and felt a bit better. But, still in pain and resumed with two to three hours of brisk walking and exercises. I noticed that many joints in my body were making cracking sound while I walk or move my body and they were continuous. They are not going away no matter how much I move that joint, the cracking sound will repeat infinite times whenever I move my body. The cracking sound is mostly from lower and upper back, shoulder, ankle, foot fingers, knees also make that cracking sound and it is painful as well. Cracking sound in knees are felt more when I start walking after being in rest state and frequency of cracking sound reduces after walking for two to three minutes.I got my ESR and CRP checked. They are normal, but there is a slight increase in lymphocytes and RBC. Now, I have been suffering from this continuous cracking sounds and pain in almost all my joints for more than a month now. I also suffer from severe pain in tail bone area. Also suffers from some sensation loss (not persistent) in left side of my upper left leg, pain in groin area (but not anymore), pain in lower back and upper back. Also a few days back a physiotherapist did some manipulation, which again increased my problem and after that when I wake up in morning both my hands are badly at asleep. Doctors say that discs are hydrated and it is rather some other thing which is causing me problems but are unable to diagnose. The amount of rest I have taken and all those manipulations have gone through have only done badly rather than doing any good. ### Response:Given the severity of your symptoms and the length of time that you have been experiencing them, it is likely that you have a more serious condition than a simple disc herniation. It is possible that you have a spinal cord compression or nerve root compression, which would explain the radiating pain, sensation loss, and joint cracking sounds. It is also possible that you have developed an autoimmune condition, which could be causing the increased lymphocytes and RBC count in your bloodwork. It is important to get further evaluation and possible imaging studies to determine the cause of your symptoms. Your doctor may also want to check thyroid function, vitamin levels, and perform a neurological exam. It is also important to get appropriate treatment, which may include physical therapy, pain management, and/or surgery.

input: Hello doctor,I concern that I have angle-closure glaucoma. I took a strong sleeping pill called Trazodone one night and woke up with a decreased vision in the right eye. My left eye became bad three weeks later. It has now been three months with no improvement. Fundus and other clinical examinations are normal. However, an OCT showed nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning.
raw_output:
Below is an instruction that describes a task, paired with an input that provides further context. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.

### Instruction:
If you are a doctor, please answer the medical questions based on the patient's description.

### Input:
Hello doctor,I concern that I have angle-closure glaucoma. I took a strong sleeping pill called Trazodone one night and woke up with a decreased vision in the right eye. My left eye became bad three weeks later. It has now been three months with no improvement. Fundus and other clinical examinations are normal. However, an OCT showed nerve fiber thinning and ganglion cell thinning.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is likely that they have angle-closure glaucoma. The decreased vision in the right eye and the subsequent worsening of the left eye indicates a possible blockage of the drainage angle in the eye, which can lead to an increase in intraocular pressure and resulting vision loss if left untreated. The OCT findings of nerve fiber and ganglion cell thinning further supports this diagnosis. A thorough ophthalmological evaluation including gonioscopy, which looks directly at the drainage angle of the eye, should be done to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate treatment.

### Response:Based on the patient's description, it is likely that they have bursitis and tendinosis. Bursitis is an inflammation of the bursa, which are fluid-filled sacs that help reduce friction between tendons and muscles and bone. Surgery may also be an option.

### Response:Hello,

Based on your description, you have a condition known as strabismus, which is a misalignment of the eyes. Your right eye has a higher power than your left eye, which is causing the eye to turn inward. This can cause amblyopia, or a lazy eye, as one eye is not used as much as the other.

At 24 years old, it is likely that your condition is not curable. However, treatment is available to help reduce the symptoms. Treatment may include glasses, eye patches, and/or eye muscle surgery.

It is also possible for your other eye to be affected, so it is important to have regular eye checkups.

As for your profession, it is possible to continue web development, but you should take regular breaks to rest your eyes and reduce strain.

I hope this information is helpful. Please feel free to contact me if you have any further questions.

Hello doctor,I had a question about the ketone diet. I honestly do not understand the benefits of a ketone diet, what are they? Is a ketone diet good for those who are diabetic?

### Response:A ketone diet is a high-fat, low-carb diet that can offer many health benefits. It is particularly beneficial for those who are looking to lose weight, reduce their risk of heart disease, and improve their overall health. For those with diabetes, a ketone diet can help regulate blood sugar levels and promote better overall health. The diet is focused on eating foods high in healthy fats, such as nuts, seeds, avocados, and oils, while limiting carbohydrates. This shift in diet can help the body burn fat instead of carbs, producing ketones which can be used for energy.
